title: Robert Gibbs defends Susan Rice on Libya
content:
Rice has been criticized for her recent 'Meet the Press ' appearance . Gibbs defends Susan Rice on Libya
Former White House press secretary Robert Gibbs defended U.N . Ambassador Susan Rice on Wednesday , hours after the State Department admitted there was no anti-American protest before the deadly assault on a U.S. diplomatic compound in Libya .
“ Let me just say this about Susan Rice : Nobody ’ s been a better public servant in this administration than Susan Rice , and I have no doubt that what Susan Rice said was exactly the intelligence assessment that she was being provided by the intelligence community in order to prepare for those appearances , ” Gibbs said on MSNBC ’ s “ Morning Joe. ” “ Nobody wants to get to the bottom of this more than the Obama administration and the White House . ”
In an appearance on “ Meet The Press ” the Sunday after the Sept. 11 attack in Benghazi , Rice said the assault came after a protest relating to an anti-Muslim video . On Tuesday night , the State Department told reporters there had been no protest .
“ I think it ’ s important to understand : Susan Rice would not have gone out there and tried to deliberately mislead anybody , ” Gibbs said . “ Susan Rice was briefed by the intelligence community , and what she was talking about on ‘ Meet the Press ’ that Sunday is exactly what the intelligence community was telling her . ”
Republicans have been attacking Rice since the appearance , with House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Peter King , a New York Republican , even calling for her resignation .
Sen. Bob Corker ( R-Tenn. ) said Rice was “ thrown under the bus ” by the Obama administration .
“ To me , this is all about a presidential election , and it ’ s all about a White House that is trying to protect this faux image , that we have in fact crushed these extremist groups around the world , ” Corker said on Fox News . “ The fact is , they ’ re mutating , the world is a very dangerous place . ”
Utah GOP Rep. Jason Chaffetz , who is chairing a congressional hearing Wednesday investigating the Benghazi attacks , said his committee had to “ pry [ facts ] out of the administration . ”
“ Look at the statements after the attack : Jay Carney , White House spokesman , Susan Rice , the State Department , the comments coming out now , we ’ re finding out those were absolutely not true , ” Chaffetz said on CNN ’ s “ Starting Point . ”
He said the White House also deserved blame for any misleading statements made after the assault , which killed U.S . Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens and three others .
“ When that intelligence information comes forward , it doesn ’ t just go to the State Department , it also goes to the White House , ” Chaffetz said . “ For the White House to claim ignorance on this is absolutely , totally not true . ”
content_original:
Rice has been criticized for her recent 'Meet the Press' appearance. Gibbs defends Susan Rice on Libya

Former White House press secretary Robert Gibbs defended U.N. Ambassador Susan Rice on Wednesday, hours after the State Department admitted there was no anti-American protest before the deadly assault on a U.S. diplomatic compound in Libya.

“Let me just say this about Susan Rice: Nobody’s been a better public servant in this administration than Susan Rice, and I have no doubt that what Susan Rice said was exactly the intelligence assessment that she was being provided by the intelligence community in order to prepare for those appearances,” Gibbs said on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.” “Nobody wants to get to the bottom of this more than the Obama administration and the White House.”

Story Continued Below

In an appearance on “Meet The Press” the Sunday after the Sept. 11 attack in Benghazi, Rice said the assault came after a protest relating to an anti-Muslim video. On Tuesday night, the State Department told reporters there had been no protest.

“I think it’s important to understand: Susan Rice would not have gone out there and tried to deliberately mislead anybody,” Gibbs said. “Susan Rice was briefed by the intelligence community, and what she was talking about on ‘Meet the Press’ that Sunday is exactly what the intelligence community was telling her.”

Republicans have been attacking Rice since the appearance, with House Homeland Security Committee Chairman Peter King, a New York Republican, even calling for her resignation.

Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) said Rice was “thrown under the bus” by the Obama administration.

“To me, this is all about a presidential election, and it’s all about a White House that is trying to protect this faux image, that we have in fact crushed these extremist groups around the world,” Corker said on Fox News. “The fact is, they’re mutating, the world is a very dangerous place.”

Utah GOP Rep. Jason Chaffetz, who is chairing a congressional hearing Wednesday investigating the Benghazi attacks, said his committee had to “pry [facts] out of the administration.”

“Look at the statements after the attack: Jay Carney, White House spokesman, Susan Rice, the State Department, the comments coming out now, we’re finding out those were absolutely not true,” Chaffetz said on CNN’s “Starting Point.”

He said the White House also deserved blame for any misleading statements made after the assault, which killed U.S. Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens and three others.

“When that intelligence information comes forward, it doesn’t just go to the State Department, it also goes to the White House,” Chaffetz said. “For the White House to claim ignorance on this is absolutely, totally not true.”

Katie Glueck contributed to this report.
